title: Liverpool news: Borussia Dortmund tried to re-sign Jurgen Klopp last year
text:
Dortmund wanted Jurgen Klopp back last year (Picture: Liverpool FC via Getty Images)

Borussia Dortmund made a bold attempt to bring Jurgen Klopp back to the club from Liverpool last year, but the move never got off the ground.

Dortmund CEO Hans-Joachim Watzke admitted to wanting Klopp to take charge at the Westfalenstadion for a second spell and he made a move to tempt the German back from Merseyside.

After a disappointing 2017/18 season, Watzke was recruiting a new manager and, although he knew it was extremely unlikely to happen, took a punt on asking Klopp if he fancied another crack at the job.

‘I knew Jurgen would fulfill his contract until the end,’ Watzke wrote in his new book, ‘Real Love – A life with Borussia Dortmund’. ‘Jurgen has always fulfilled his contracts. That’s how he is.

‘But if you want to go in new ways, and I wanted a new path at BVB at this point, then I at least had to ask Jurgen to consider.

Advertisement

Advertisement

‘I would not have forgiven myself for not asking him at that moment.’

With Klopp still in charge of Liverpool, leading them to the Champions League title in June and currently sitting pretty at the top of the Premier League, we know how the story ends.

It is also no surprise that the 52-year-old gave the suggestion pretty short shrift, with his contract at Anfield running until 2023.

‘My phone rang while I was on the plane Aki was on it: “Jürgen, you have to come back.” I thought he was kidding,’ said Klopp of the surprise call from Watzke (known as Aki).

‘Are you stupid? Have you been drinking? How did you get the idea? I’ve got a few more years in Liverpool.’

Klopp has not ruled out a return to Dortmund at some point in his career, although he admits that it does not seem a probable step.

‘As a rescuer in need, if the club really needs my help – why should not I do that?’ said Klopp. ‘It’s very nice that I even have the opportunity. But, I admit, it does not seem so likely.

‘There’s always something new to come.’
